element.p: Earth system scientists take a holistic view of planet Earth, working to gain understanding of the influence of major and minor processes on Earth’s past, current and future conditions. Much of Earth systems science is focused on understanding what drives Earth’s global, regional and local climate patterns, including human activity. A major goal is to improve predictions of future climate under various scenarios of human actions and other variables.
View this video to get a sense of how and why NASA studies our planet.

top.p: Earth system scientists are not the only ones to think about how nature is interconnected.

bottom.quote: Learn how to see. Realize that everything is connected to everything else.

The indigenous understanding has its basis of spirituality in a recognition of the interconnectedness and interdependence of all living things, a holistic and balanced view of the world. All things are bound together. All things connect. What happens to the Earth happens to the children of the earth.
In nature we never see anything isolated, but everything in connection with something else which is before it, beside it, under it and over it.

element.p: Earth system scientists employ systems thinking to gain understanding of how Earth’s overall system works.
A system can be defined as a group of interacting, interrelated, or interdependent components that work together to form a complex whole.

A familiar example of a system with interdependent components is the human body. The components of the human body’s system are the skeletal system, nervous system, circulatory system, digestive system, etc.
Each component is made up of elements. For example, the elements of the circulatory system include blood cells, veins, arteries and heart.
The interaction of components and their interrelated processes create system behavior.
In Earth systems science, the main components of planet Earth are considered to be

list.item: Air (Atmosphere)
Land (Geosphere)
Water - the ocean and freshwater (Hydrosphere)
Ice, snow, glaciers, ice sheets, ice caps (Cryosphere)
All living things (Biosphere)

element.note: Some scientists include Cryosphere as a component of the Hydrosphere, and some scientists include the Pedosphere, a.k.a. soils, as a component of the Geosphere.

element.p: Earth system scientists seek to improve our understanding of each of these spheres, as well as the interactions between them, to better predict long and short-term changes on our planet.
Earth system scientists use the scientific method; a simplified version is outlined here.

list.item: Make observations
Ask a question
Make a prediction that is testable (a hypothesis)
Test the prediction
Share the results with peers (usually via a science journal or at a science conference)
Use the results and peer feedback to refine the question, ask new questions, make new predictions and/or solidify predictions.

element.p: You may wonder how a scientist could test hypotheses about Earth processes or run an experiment on the entire planet. Scientists employ a variety of modes of inquiry in their analysis of Earth’s systems and processes, including

list.item: Conducting laboratory experiments
Observing change over time
Comparing ancient artifacts with products of current day processes
Observing spatial gradients
Use of physical models
Computer modeling

element.h2subheader: Laboratory experiment
element.p: For example, scientists can test chemical reactions and physical processes on small scales in lab settings, such as exposing tanks of phytoplankton to various temperatures to determine the effect of warming oceans on plankton blooms.

element.h2subheader: Observing change over time
element.p: For example, with the aid of ground-based, airborne and satellite data, scientists detect changes in regional and global land, air and ocean temperature.

element.h2subheader: Comparing ancient artifacts with products of current day processes
element.p: For example, geologists researching how this cave formed at Craters of the Moon NPP can get clues by examining active lava tubes at places like Hawai’i Volcanoes National Park.

image.alt: Two images. first image is lava tube cave at craters of the moon national park and preserve. second image is lava tube at hawai'i volcanoes

element.h2subheader: Observing spatial gradients
element.p: This can lead to hypotheses for causation (ex., a gradient of coarse to fine grains often leads to hypotheses of direction of sediment transport).

element.h2subheader: Use of physical models
element.p: One example of a physical model is a stream table, which can be used for analyzing the physics of stream flow.

element.h2subheader: Computer modeling
element.p: Global climate models allow scientists to manipulate one or several variables to explore causation of changes in processes and make predictions.

list.item: The discipline of Earth system science is characterized by a holistic systems-thinking approach to studying our home planet.
Systems are comprised of interactive, interrelated or interdependent components that work together to form a complex whole.
Each component is made up of elements.
The Earth system components are the Atmosphere, Geosphere, Hydrosphere, Cryosphere and Biosphere.
Earth system scientists employ the scientific method and a variety of modes of inquiry to research the processes and behavior of Earth’s component spheres and the system as a whole.

element.section: Part 2: Looking at Earth as a System and Applying That to Your Site

quoteElement.quote: Look deep into nature, and then you will understand everything better.

element.p: In this section we’ll be exploring your site using an Earth systems approach. We’ll help you think about each sphere, and the elements, processes and cycles in each. We’ll help you use your image to identify and label evidence of these things in the landscape in which you work and/or live.
The Earth system with all of its spheres is sometimes referred to as a "system of systems."

Each sphere functions as an open system: the spheres are connected through matter cycling and energy flowing between them, and a variety of global processes. For example, water and carbon are found in every sphere, cycling between them.
Scientists use the concept of Earth’s spheres as a means of studying the complexity of the planet.

element.main: Each Sphere is Made Up of Elements

element.main: Using Your Site Photo to Explore a Systems View of Your Site

list.item: Find the photo you took of your site, and the tracing paper or plastic overlay.

element.h2subheader: Elements of the Geosphere includes the surface rocks and soils as well as Earth's interior.
element.p: Take a look at your photo of your site. Can you identify a few elements of the Geosphere at your location? Label them on your overlay or sketch.
element.hint: The Geosphere includes: the solid part of Earth (mountains, valleys, fields, plains, bedrock, etc.); the not-so-solid interior of the Earth; and the thin layer of soil that covers parts of the solid Earth.

element.h2subheader: Elements of the Hydrosphere include all bodies of surface water as well as ground water.
element.p: Take a look at your photo of your site. Can you identify a few elements of the Hydrosphere at your location? Label them on your overlay or sketch.
element.hint: The Hydrosphere is all of Earth's bodies of water, including oceans, lakes, rivers, and even the groundwater and Earth's frozen water. As in this tutorial, climate scientists often categorize frozen water as the Cryosphere, while also recognizing it as a part of the Hydrosphere.

element.h2subheader: Elements of the Cryosphere include snow and ice.
element.p: Take a look at your photo of your site. Can you identify a few elements of the Cryosphere at your location? Label them on your overlay or sketch.
element.hint: The Cryosphere is water in its frozen form on Earth’s surface. This includes ice and snow on the ground, sea ice, lake and river ice, glaciers, ice shelves, icebergs and frozen ground (soil or rock in which all or part of the water is frozen). Ground that is frozen all year round is called permafrost.

element.h2subheader: Elements of the Biosphere include all living plants and animals, from the smallest single celled organisms to the largest trees and animals on the planet.
element.p: Take a look at your photo of your site. Can you identify a few elements of the Biosphere at your location? Label them on your overlay or sketch.
element.hint: The Biosphere is the collection of all living things on Earth: plants, animals, bacteria, fungi, algae, and protozoa.

element.h2subheader: Elements of the Atmosphere include several different gases (mostly nitrogen and oxygen) as well as clouds, water vapor, and solid particles such as dust and pollen.
element.p: Take a look at your photo of your site. Can you identify a few elements of the Atmosphere at your location? Label them on your overlay or sketch.
element.hint: The Atmosphere is the blanket of gas that we call air that surrounds Earth. The Atmosphere includes the rain that is falling through the air, clouds, and tiny suspended particles of dust (called aerosols) that are found in air.

element.h2subheader: Each Sphere Holds Matter and Energy
element.p: Energy in the spheres is mostly in the form of heat energy or chemical energy. There is a vast amount of heat energy in the Atmosphere and Hydrosphere. The greatest source of this heat energy is the Sun.

Although it is obvious that the Hydrosphere and Cryosphere hold water, there is also water in the Biosphere, Atmosphere, and in the Geosphere. Each of the spheres also holds oxygen, various forms of carbon, and other chemical elements or materials. All of the matter on Earth can be placed in one or more spheres.

element.h2subheader: Earth’s Spheres are Interconnected by the Flow and Exchange of Energy and Matter
element.p: Energy and matter are always circulating among the spheres, connecting them in many ways. Sometimes this circulation can happen very quickly, such as when a volcano erupts, moving tons of tiny particles from the Geosphere into the Atmosphere. Other examples of circulation happen much more slowly, such as when a fallen tree decays and nutrients move from the Biosphere to the Geosphere.

element.h2subheader: Energy is transferred within and between spheres
element.p: For example:

list.item: The sun warms the ground (Geosphere), which transfers its heat to the Atmosphere by radiation.
Warm air transfers heat to cooler land surfaces by conduction.
Rivers and ocean currents move heat energy from one place to another by convection.

element.h2subheader: Energy is transferred within and between spheres
element.p: Take another look at your site photo. Can you identify one or two ways in which energy is flowing, and being transferred within and between spheres? Diagram this on your overlay or sketch.
element.videolink: Learn more about the Carbon Cycle

element.p: Carbon, the major building block of life, continuously cycles within and between the spheres. The carbon cycle is one of the most important interconnections within the Earth system.

element.h2subheader: Whenever matter moves from one sphere into another, some process, driven by energy, causes it to happen. Here are some examples:
element.p: Water moves from a lake (Hydrosphere) into the air (Atmosphere) by a process called evaporation.

element.h2subheader: Whenever matter moves from one sphere into another, some process, driven by energy, causes it to happen. Here are some examples:
element.p: Carbon dioxide moves from your body (Biosphere) into the air (Atmosphere) by a process called respiration.

element.h2subheader: Whenever matter moves from one sphere into another, some process, driven by energy, causes it to happen. Here are some examples:
element.p: Minerals move from rock (Geosphere) into streams (Hydrosphere) by the processes of weathering and erosion.

element.h2subheader: Whenever matter moves from one sphere into another, some process, driven by energy, causes it to happen. Here are some examples:
element.p: Nutrients and carbon move from a plant (Biosphere) into a bird’s body (Biosphere) by the processes of consumption and digestion.

list.item: The Earth system behaves as a single, self-regulating system with physical, chemical, and biological processes.
The interactions and feedbacks between the system’s components are complex and take place on multiple scales of time and space.

The focus of Earth system science is understanding the interactions between the oceans and ice, atmosphere, life, geological processes and the land surface, and how those interactions impact each other and lead to changes on our planet.

element.h2subheader: Our planet’s climate system operates at global, regional and local scales, which are linked.
element.p: For example, pollution from China affects cloud development in the North Pacific and strengthens extratropical cyclones. In turn, these play an important role in atmospheric circulation, bringing tropical moisture up to temperate latitudes.

element.section: What Drives Earth’s Climate on the Global Scale?
element.h2subheader: Physics
element.p: The laws of physics govern how air and water move and affect atmospheric and oceanic circulation patterns, among other things. Climate scientists rely on known understanding of physics when developing climate models and predictions of climate.

Conservation of Energy
Conservation of Momentum
Conservation of Angular Momentum
Newton’s Universal Law of Gravity

element.section: What Drives Earth’s Climate on the Global Scale?
element.h2subheader: Presence of life
element.p: We have seen that living things help circulate matter and energy. Life also contributes to the greenhouse gases that help make Earth’s temperature habitable for people.

element.section: What Drives Earth’s Climate on the Global Scale?
element.h2subheader: Cycling of matter
element.p: The cycling of matter links the Earth system components. Examples include the water cycle and the carbon cycle. Alterations in these cycles can cause climate to shift (eg., adding excess CO<sub>2</sub> to the atmosphere traps more heat on Earth, in turn changing the climate.)

element.section: What Drives Earth’s Climate on the Global Scale?
element.h2subheader: Coupled ocean and atmospheric circulation determine climate patterns
element.p: A major part of the global climate system is comprised of the coupled ocean and atmospheric circulation patterns. These patterns dictate the major climatic zones on our planet and are intimately intertwined with all of Earth’s spheres.
A basic understanding of these circulation patterns can help us grasp the global, regional and local ramifications of the changes humans are making to our Atmosphere and ocean.
Let’s begin with the Atmosphere.

element.section: What Drives Earth’s Climate on the Global Scale?
element.h2subheader: Cumulative effects of regional and local processes and events
element.p: For example, cumulative effects of land management practices in various regions around the globe affect the global carbon cycle, in turn impacting global climate.

element.section: What Causes Variation in Regional Climate?
element.p: Regional climate patterns involve smaller scale events and processes. They can also be affected by cyclical events that are linked to the global climate. For example, the El Niño - La Niña cycle arises from global oceanic processes. The switch from one phase of this cycle to another impacts climate and weather patterns in Pacific coastal regions and beyond.

element.caption: One example of regional climate patterns is the El Niño/La Niña cycle, which arises from global oceanic processes. The switch from one phase of this cycle to another impacts climate and weather patterns in Pacific coastal regions and beyond.

element.section: What Causes Variation in Local Climate?
element.h2subheader: Cumulative effects of regional and local processes and events
element.p: Local climate is dependent upon global and regional processes but is influenced by the local environment and conditions such as topography or land cover.

element.section: Why is Earth’s Climate Changing Now?
element.p: By altering the chemical makeup of our Atmosphere through adding additional carbon, we are trapping more of the Sun’s energy. This changes both the Atmosphere and ocean components of Earth’s climate system, which in turn affect the Biosphere, Cryosphere and Geosphere in ways that have global, regional and local consequences.

element.section: How is Your Site Linked to the Global Climate System?
element.p: Think how the ocean and air currents affect the climate where you live. Do you think the system is changing? Have weather patterns shifted in your location? How might this affect the natural and cultural resources there? How about the global and local processes, the energy flow and the exchange of matter? How will all of these changes affect you, and your visitors? Our longer courses use an Earth systems approach to build the conceptual links between global, regional and local climate change and frame discussions with scientists and fellow interpreters.
Earth’s climate operates on global, regional and local scales, which are linked through various processes governed by fundamental laws of physics.
Globally, Earth’s climate is determined by the Sun’s cycles, Earth’s orbital cycles, the cycling of matter and flow of energy, and the cumulative effects of regional and local processes.
The currents of the ocean and the Atmosphere are inextricably linked, distributing heat around the planet. This produces global, regional and local climate and weather patterns.
Regional climate is dependent on global trends, influenced by regional conditions such as land management practices.
Local climate is impacted by both regional and global scale processes, influenced by localized conditions such as impervious surfaces.

Earth’s climate is changing because humans are adding excess carbon to the Atmosphere. This is altering all components of the Earth system, leading to widespread impacts at local, regional and global scales.

As you learn more about Earth’s climate and global change, or even as you simply think about what is happening in the natural world around you, keep in mind the concept of the Earth system, with its spheres, reservoirs of matter and energy, and processes that drive matter and energy from one sphere to another.
These concepts can help you better understand the very dynamic nature of our planet and provide a foundation for explaining global climate change and its effects.
It’s all about connections!
